Award.AwardTitle: Transitioning the US Military Population to the Civilian Workforce in STEM Fields

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides scholarships to academically able and financially needy students who are military veterans and who are majoring in Biology, Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, Geography and Environmental Science, Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering. The objectives of this project are to: 1) provide academic scholarships to attain a bachelor's degree within a STEM discipline; 2) expand upon student support structures (e.g. mentoring, counseling services, student organizations, etc.) to better accommodate the needs of this growing population, and 3) assist with employment in the civilian workforce or the pursuit of STEM graduate programs after graduation.

Intellectual Merit: The academic programs into which the students go are strong. The project emphasizes supporting students through faculty mentoring, close interaction among groups of students, and internships. Local industries are supportive and are providing mentoring and internship opportunities.

Broader Impact: The project is increasing the number and diversity of students who complete a STEM major and go on to work in the field or to further education. The project addresses a national issue and can serve as a model for other institutions to follow. In addition to assisting an under-served population that makes great personal sacrifices for our country, this program taps into a pool of hard-working and motivated individuals and supports efforts to increase the number of potential employees in STEM industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, the NSF Military STEM Scholarship Program was implemented at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs (UCCS).  The overall goal of this program was to provide support to military veterans to ensure that they graduate and successfully transition into professional careers in STEM.  In addition to assisting an underserved and growing population of individuals who make notable sacrifices for our Country, this program addresses a national issue by tapping into a pool of dedicated and technically skilled individuals as a means to increase the number of qualified STEM professionals in the United States.  Along with financial assistance, this program utilized existing institutional support structures to provide the scholars with mentorship and guidance to facilitate a successful transition to a STEM professional career, which include the Career Services Center, the Writing Center, and the Office of Veteran and Military Student Affairs.   Based on our experiences from Year 1, many scholars were unprepared to pursue opportunities that could enhance their success in STEM profession because they did not know how to put together an effective resume.  As a result, new scholars were required to visit the Career Services Center to review their resumes, and all scholars had to update their resumes on an annual basis.  We also instituted the requirement that all scholars had to demonstrate involvement in at least one activity per semester that improved success of attaining their future career goals, such as attending a conference or obtaining an internship.  Furthermore, many of the scholars felt isolated at the University and had difficulty relating to the other students.  To address this issue, scholars were required to participate in at least one activity that contributes to improving the environment for military service members at UCCS.  Scholars were encouraged to join the Student Veterans Organization, an established student-led club that organizes community outreach programs, social events, and networking for veteran students of all disciplines.      

Through this program, scholarships were awarded to 56 veterans pursuing a STEM degree at UCCS, which exceeded our target goal of 24-48 awards.   The success of our program is reflected in the accomplishments of our STEM scholars.   To date, 51.2% (29 scholars) have graduated with a STEM degree.  As indicated in Table 1, 96.7% (28/29) have successfully transitioned into STEM employment or a STEM graduate program, such as medical school, doctoral program at UC Irvine, math instructor at a community college, and full-time positions at local and national engineering companies.  The remaining graduate is currently seeking STEM employment.   The majority (22/29) have transitioned to full-time employment in a STEM profession (at least 7 with previous internships leading to employment).  Employers include: Lockheed Martin, Northrup Grumman, Xorail, Sanborn Map Company, Global Mapping Solutions, Evoqua, U.S. Air Force, U.S. Forest Service, and U.S. Fish and Wildlife.   Six of our graduates are pursuing advanced degrees, which include a MD at UCLA, a PhD at UC Santa Barbara, and a Doctor of Pharmacy at the University of Georgia.  Among the 6 that are pursuing advance degrees, 5 had previous undergraduate research positions or internships.

In the last year of funding, we shifted efforts from program implementation (i.e. recruiting strategies and establishing infrastructure) to program evaluation.  Through surveys, discussions and focus groups, this program has promoted many activities that scholars have accredited to their success, including networking opportunities, the acquisition of internships, the use of free student support services, and providing leadership roles.  We are currently analyzing data and drafting a manuscript based on our findings.  As stated by one of our scholars during a focus group meeting, “When you’re in the military, you’re told what to do step-by-step what’s going to happen next.  When you get into college, your making your own plans and doing your own school work.  You have to make plans your own way without relying on other people telling you what to do.  This scholarship itself has helped me put it all together rather than trying to think of it myself of what I need to do.   You know, go out for an internship earlier than I thought I would.  Obviously it makes sense when you say it, but it’s not something I would have thought about before.”

We have utilized the experiences from this program to provide guidance on developing other scholarship programs.  Our final goal is to disseminate the project findings so that this program can serve as a model for other academic institutions to better serve our growing military student population.
